title: DReSD: Dense Retrieval for Speculative Decoding
author: Milan Gritta (Huawei Noah's Ark Lab, London, UK), Huiyin Xue (University of Sheffield, UK), Gerasimos Lampouras (Huawei Noah's Ark Lab, London, UK)
relevance_why: The proposed dense retrieval methods could enhance audio-language modeling tasks by improving the efficiency and accuracy of token generation, relevant to Haohe Liu's research in speech and audio.
background: This research addresses the challenge of speeding up token generation in large language models while maintaining accuracy through an innovative speculative decoding framework that uses dense retrieval.
contribution: DReSD introduces a dense retrieval mechanism for speculative decoding to resolve the inefficiencies of sparse retrieval, achieving significantly higher acceptance rates and faster generation speeds.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous methods relied on sparse retrieval, which often faced limitations in precision and recall due to exact string matching.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work improves by implementing approximate nearest neighbor search with contextualized token embeddings, enhancing the retrieval accuracy.

key_innovation: It uniquely applies dense retrieval techniques to speculative decoding, enabling LLMs to generate token sequences more efficiently.
real_world_impact: The proposed method could greatly benefit real-time applications such as conversational agents and automated coding assistants by providing quicker and more relevant responses.
limitations: No notable limitations were discussed by the authors.

new_terms.speculative decoding: **Speculative decoding** is a process that improves token generation speed by using a smaller draft model to propose tokens that are later verified by a larger language model.
new_terms.dense retrieval: **Dense retrieval** refers to a retrieval method based on semantic similarity, using contextualized embeddings and approximating nearest neighbor search rather than relying on exact matches.

open_sourcing: The code and data are available at https://github.com/huawei-noah/HEBO/tree/DReSD
